Civilization VII is a huge disappointment. While fine on its own, it pales in comparison to previous titles in the series. The main problem is a clear lack of care or originality put into its design. This is perfectly represented by the different music in this game and the last, Civilization VI. While VI's soundtrack is original, awesome, and beautiful, VII's is the most bland, stereotypical strategy game music imaginable. Do not spend $70 on this game, just play CIV6.

Civ 7's age system sucks. The legacy path mechanic railroads you through each age, and the transition between ages is disruptive and unsatisfying. As a result, the immersion is gone. In every other Civ game you feel like you are leading your people, but in Civ 7 it's impossible to escape the feeling that you are playing a game.

There's a lot else wrong with Civ 7, but that's expected. Civ games have a storied history of launching in rough shape before being molded into a quality game. I don't think Civ 7 will get there because this time around, they tinkered with one of the core Civ systems and fundamentally broke it. It doesn't feel like Civ anymore.

Played Civ V, VI, VII. The VII brings about a revolutionary gameplay in the series. Despite having the same theme, it manifests a different feel to the game: not only presenting extra flavourings to the same game as its predecessors have done. With respect to achieving their objectives in producing this instalment, I dare say that they have succeeded. Several balancing and bug fixing are still in order at the time of writing, but the developer team seems eager to perfect the game and listen to community responses. I'd also recommend [i]all[/i] the DLCs, especially for Civ fans. The first 100 hours adjustment period from the previous instalment may be difficult, but it will be followed by a simple, binary conviction: like or dislike.

Civilization VII Review (Based on 88 Hours of Gameplay): A Strategy Game That Forgot Strategy

As someone who has played over 88 hours of Civilization VII and spent countless hours in Civ VI, I can confidently say that Civ VII is visually refined―but strategically hollow. The game focuses almost entirely on warfare, while the depth and variety that once defined the series seem largely stripped away.

Where Did the Strategy Go?

In Civ VI, players had multiple ways to win and interact with the world:

Religious wars with missionaries and apostles clashing ideologically.

World Congress voting, where nations united to free oppressed city-states.

Global trade routes that boosted economy, culture, and diplomacy.

Strategic resource gathering, where uranium, oil, or iron dictated your military path.
All these mechanics gave the player freedom to pursue science, diplomacy, culture, or religion over pure conquest.


In Civ VII, almost all of that is gone―or oversimplified to the point of irrelevance.

Just Fight―But Why?

Every game ends up being about war. You’re pushed into fighting not because of ideological conflict, resource scarcity, or diplomatic failure―but simply because that’s all there is to do.
Even if you try to build a peaceful nation, the AI constantly pressures you. And when a small nation is attacked, there is no world vote to protect them or establish peace like there used to be. Diplomacy is shallow and often meaningless.

You don’t feel like a leader managing a civilization. You feel like a general commanding troops with no deeper purpose.

No Need for Strategy

There's no meaningful trading.

Resources don’t matter much―you can go to war without worrying about having iron or oil.

The city cap system punishes expansion, even if you try to play tall or wide.

Religion is bland, lacking the depth and battles of Civ VI.

Victory conditions feel imbalanced; most paths force you into war.


The Only Bright Spots

Yes, the graphics are better. Yes, some UI improvements are welcome. And yes, multiplayer runs more smoothly. But that’s not enough to compensate for the loss of depth, freedom, and replayability.

Conclusion:

Civ VII is a turn-based war simulator, not a true civilization-building strategy game. It lacks the soul of its predecessors. As someone who loved the layers of planning, diplomacy, and global interaction in Civ VI, this new version feels like a huge step backwards.

My Rating: 6.5/10

Definitely launched in an unfinished state, but the subsequent updates have improved things a fair bit. The core ideas have some absolute gold in them, and this could become the best Civ game with a bit of effort from the devs.

Everybody will focus on the ages and the switching of your civ as the problem here but they are only half correct, imo. The switching of civs is a neat mechanic and it can be implemented properly. The real problem is the attempt to curb "snowballing" and resetting the majority of the game between the ages. This isn't Mario Kart, we don't need blue shells. Civ should be a drawn out strategy game where key decision points can alter the course of the game, especially early on. If we're going to play three short games the importance of strategy is lessened greatly and removes the joy of playing a strategy game! If you got out-snowballed start another game and don't let people get ahead of you on the tech tree! The main problem that creates snowballing is the tech tree and there are ways to keep that in check without completely breaking the game up into separate sections. It doesn't let the player invest in the game, it encourages you to just collect your points and move on until eventually <poof!> you're at the end of an age or the entire game. It feels abrupt and unwelcome. It could have been cool as a game mode but as the entire game - it's a terrible design choice and I'll probably never come back to this game as a result.

For long time fans who wonder what flavor(s) of Civ are my favorite: I've been playing since CivNet and got super into Civ II, and then again at Civ 4. Of the modern era I really like 5 and only sorta like 6, so maybe I'm just an old fuddy duddy but I think this strays way too far from the winning formula to be good. Sorry, Firaxis, better luck next time.

There are other issues that really bother me: the map generation is terrible, as is the UI, but I think these are things (along with sparse game systems) that can be pretty easily updated moving forward and that's the norm for Civ games - iterative improvement. But I doubt they will ever drop the hard resets and age transitions since they think that is the core of this game. Unfortunately, I think they are choosing to die on a very poor hill. Fingers crossed for some better, fresh ideas in 8, until then see y'all in 5. :)

Been playing since Civ 1: yes a long time. Not going to compare this game with earlier iterations as they all have their pros and cons. This version though is boringly horrible.
1. I've played most of the leaders (at Governor, couple at Viceroy) to get a handle on the game, and won most, despite the era changes wiping out most of my troops, destroying many of the buildings and or eating up all my gold. I even lost a level 7 commander during one era change. After the era change the troop balance and distribution is totally different to what I had in the earlier era (before end of era attrition).
Also, why does religion play such an important role in the end of era attrition? I hate religion in all civ versions and in real life. Some of the narrative options give the option of downplaying religion so why not also downplay the religious effects at the end of Antiquity based on the options you've chosen?
2. The tech tree and civic tree are boring: even though all the leaders and civs are supposedly different, they all have to follow the same tech order. Its very tedious even if there are civ/leader buffs along the way. I do like the civilisation tree each era, although I don't like having different civilisations each era.
3. The maps are sooo....... Two continents, with various bits and pieces cut out, plus vertical archipelagoes between the continents. Come on...
4. The settlement allowance, whether cities or towns, is ridiculously low especially if you aim for the military victory line in whichever era. Whenever you take another player's settlement you have the option of keeping or razing, fair enough. However, whether you opt to keep or raze, the settlement counts towards your own settlement count: that's ok if you keep the settlement, but not ok if you opt for razing as it still counts as a settlement even though you are getting no benefit whatsoever.
5. Too much micromanagement of units especially as more of the globe is opened up and your civ is settled far and wide. There is no autoexplore option for scouts which is a big miss. Setting units to go from A to B is simple, BUT you have to watch these units carefully. Settlers will always change their route moving towards unfriendly units. Land troops appear to prefer travelling over rivers and water tiles, making them more vulnerable to attack, and also like moving towards unfriendly ships and troops. All land autorouting seems to ignor existing roads/rail.

Let me say I understand all the hate this game is getting. The codex needs more information and there are still bugs. However, Civ 7 is still a great game and this is coming from someone with 1200+ hours between Civ V and VI.
After a couple games I've grown to really love the age system, there are 3 "mini games" within one overall game. I like trying to balance my accomplishments within the ages while also trying to plan for future ages, it makes for interesting strategy. I would highly recommend getting the popular mods from nexus mods (sounds llike workshop support will be added soon, so use that once its available). I would also recommend checking reddit/civpedia for any concepts that aren't well explained - you'll be able to find any answers you need out there.

TLDR - Great addictive Civ game, highly recommend (despite all the hate it's getting). Use mods & do research on anything that isn't clear.

I have not finished this game yet, but damn it is incredible. I started playing this game via game pass, but quickly realized that this game deserved to be bought. 
	This game specially was created for exploration type of players and Obsidian did it so well. I was often catching myself thinking that this game is literally everything I wanted from an action RPG game - the story, immersion, the game world itself, movement, hero progression, builds, art design (visually this game is something else) - everything is so good, and verticality… oh verticality, as a level designer myself I envy Obsidian’s level designers that they have a possibility to work on the project like that.
Avowed took everything best from old school RPGs and combined it with modern technologies and engines.
	Thank you Obsidian again for creating another masterpiece, and thank you for reminding me how a real game should look and feel.

[h1]SOLID DEBUT[/h1]

AVOWED is a game that will immerse you within a vibrant and charming fantastical world. Avowed has some of the best exploration I've seen in a game I'm constantly overwhelmed with excitement whenever I find myself going off the beaten path in search for loot and secrets, speaking of loot the game never fails to reward your curiosity I have to constantly make sure there isn't a stone unturned before progressing never know when a small hole in the wall will lead to epic loot. The game's narrative is enriched with lore that shapes the story's journey through the living lands, creating conflict between factions and ideologies that leave you struggling to make choices that will bring the best outcome for you and those within the living lands. While the lore is good unfortunately I can't say the same for the story. Now on paper it does sound like a compelling narrative but it felt like the execution was weak. The characters I find myself disinterested in what they have to say not saying they don't have tragic backstories and quirks to make them stand out but they just don't explore those interesting bits about the character enough or just leave the interesting character developments towards the end of the game. The combat in AVOWED might actually be the best in the entire RPG Genre. I've played exclusively as a wizard in my playthrough and I felt like I was playing DOOM with a wand and the grimoire has some jaw dropping spells that had me trying to optimize the best build that would create absolute mayham when enemies start flooding the screen, companions felt almost completely useless in dealing damage or creating distractions when it comes to dealing with enemies. The enemies always seem to focus you and companions felt like they were trying to not kill the enemy just so the player could land a combo with a killing blow making them utterly useless.

Conclusion:
Overall I felt AVOWED was a solid game, a good game. Not a great game, not an amazing game, not the best the genre has to offer just a good solid game. I highly recommend it despite the shortcomings. But with that being said I recommend trying it on XBOX GAME PASS or get it for half the price when it goes on sale. If you want to live out the power fantasy of being a wizard then you'll find the combat in AVOWED is much more satisfying than those you find at Hogwarts, if you love an adventure that will constantly side track you with curious looking biomes and ruins with loot then look no further than this charming little High Fantasy RPG called AVOWED.

Overall Score: 7/10

As a Pillars of Eternity fan, it's no surprise that I think Avowed's art and writing are top-notch. What I didn't expect was how fluid and interesting the combat would be. This game is straight-up fun.

I see a lot of hate for this game, why?

Really, it's a fun game in the end. And comparing it to other games because it's not like them is kind of silly. If it was, the big complaint would be it's a carbon copy of xxxx. Ultimately it's less sim RPG and more action RPG, so it is simplified in some ways. Which is fine by me.
The story does a good job of moving the game/player along and there's so much loot, in fact in many ways it's more like a fantasy version of Borderlands. Plus if you fall in love with a certain load out you can upgrade it so it still stays relevant. Even combat reminds me more of Borderlands than anything else and is a blast.
I have encountered a few annoying bugs. Occasionally the game will stop responding to the majority of buttons including escape. The only solution is to use task manager to end the game and restart. Plus it will occasionally hang when closing and again need to be manually closed. Plus the MSRP is a bit too high for me, so I waited for a sale.

My advice is give it a a shot and refund it if you don't like what you find. Easy peasy...
Plenty of quests, equipment and resources. Good game play. It's not too easy (I've died a few times) and not too hard either.

about 40 hours in and I actually like the game for what it is. The story is interesting and the combat is fun. Just FYI, this is NOT an RPG. This game is an open world action game, think borderlands with magic and mid-evil setting. If that sounds up your alley, get it.

I was trying to enjoy the game despite the absolutely horrific controls. (dodge mechanics are absolutely awful).  Tired of playing a serious dis-advantage (characters with shields can block anything that isn't a power attack but mages only have the terrible dodge that isn't helpful against the enemy that can spam attacks).  And being the only one worried about "ammo".  Mages use mana, but mana doesn't regen.  Archers get infinite arrows.  NPCs get infinite grenades and mana.  And mages not only have to worry about mana, but stamina...which is what is used for dodge.

So as a mage you're unable to block anything, have less health than all other classes, and have the weakest attack unless you use a spell that uses a finite amount of essence.

Not to mention.  Every spell is of a element type that you run into things that are resistant or completely immune to.  So...to kill everything you need 100 or 200 times your full mana of spells to defeat them.

This creates a combat experience that is akin to playing a high speed platformer.  Dodge at just the right times.  Maybe you'll get a chance to land a hit every so often.

Then in comes cylia.  The boss that spams AOE healing....
Yeah, hard pass.  I tried to have fun.  I failed.

Avowed feels like classic Obsidian - a little narrower and more guided than other open-world RPGs, in exchange for a focus on rich storytelling and consequential moral choices.  The downside is that the game never truly surprises you or leaves you to fend for yourself, and combat is easy and eventually becomes repetitive.  The game also refers to individual NPCs as "they" and carefully makes those characters gender-neutral, which will be controversial for some.  But the upside is that the world feels genuinely alive and detailed - there's always an NPC or a treasure chest or a piece of lore around the next corner, the worldbuilding is extensive and unique, and the story offers you a wide array of roleplaying options without commenting on whether any of them is "good" or "bad."  I enjoyed my time with the game and thought it was a breath of fresh air as more RPGs rely on procedurally generated worlds that feel shallow and dead.

Great game! While the story and characters are not extremely appealing the game play and environment make it worth your while. If you're looking for something with extreme depth,  its probably not for you, but if you just want to run around and explore in a first person RPG that isn't made by Bethesda, look no further.

I'm still far from finishing the stroy, however I felt the urge to share my thoughts on this game.
Please, please, PLEASE! Don't be as dumb as me and buy this game for the full price or "only" 20% discount.
It's a good game, don't get me wrong, it's pretty solid and I enjoy my time playing it.
Hella pretty, fun characters, love the exploring and an okay-ish fighting system.
HOWEVER! It kind of sucks at holding my attention / motivation continuing this game. 
In conclusion: Get this game, it's fun enough, but only on a massive discount when you can buy it for like 20 bucks.

I played this for almost 30 hours, I just cant .. I cant go on anymore. There are very few good things I can really say about it.

The only real positive thing I can say is it is really very colorful and the day night cycle brings a sort of life to the lands. I liked the very beginning of the game, It set up what was happening very well. I'm wrecked at a supposed friendly outpost at behest of the emperor of the most powerful empire in the known world. Good times ensue from there.

The list of items that I did not like about this game is very long. The most glaring is that nobody treats you like an envoy from an emperor. It is said I am an embodiment of his will and bring his law wherever my eyes rest. This couldn't be farther from the truth. The part that ended my run is when a town of very dangerous practitioners of soul magic (outlawed in my kingdom, and very obviously a bad idea) gets burned down by allies of our emperor. This seems like a very good idea to me, but the game wanted me to feel bad for them and go against the agents of the emperor. I had no decision over the matter going so far as to make me basically declare war on them after the event. It made no sense. There's a farm of the undead right over there, the only thing keeping them from ripping our throats out is a collar. These people are the worst.

An annoying component is the weapon upgrade system it is pointless. I can spend all my money and scavenge around (stealing) to upgrade my weapon to the next "tier", and then after futzing with that for a long while, find the exact same thing or better in the next area. Just a horrible game mechanic. (and god forbid my companions do anything of importance during a fight, i would really hate for them to chip a nail or something.)

I could just go on and on about bad thing. The wierdos that join up with you whether you want them to or not,  the crash that hit me every three hours, the treasure that was just laying about everywhere, the writing of almost every story telling element.... there is so much more, i mean there is so much that went wrong here. I think I've already spent more energy than I should have on this. 

This makes the third game in a row that I have just hated for the mechanics and the writing. Its like people don't actually play the games they make.

I really tried to give this a chance. Turned out to be nothing more than a woke DEI agenda pusher, comparatively worse graphics and gameplay than every other MMORPG since 2005. It's almost as if they uploaded a lesbian DEI advisor's consciousness to an AI and told it to build a game, but gave it absolutely no idea what a game even was supposed to look like or play like, with no concept of basic physics, and then to top it all off, asked it to write the single worst dialogue set ever seen on earth since neanderthals learned to speak.

Please don't buy this. Not even on sale. You'll be so annoyed and genuinely have the feeling you could've spent that money on literally anything else with less regret.

Just go play oblivion remastered instead for better gameplay, or BG3 for better story.

It feels empty, lackluster, and devoid of soul or originality. Builds are cookie cutter and offer no chance at a unique approach. Difficulty is trivial and a slog.

Uninstalled near the end with no desire to even see it through. Not captivating enough for the new standards being shown in gaming by smaller studios.

I'd recommend this game to those RPG fans who enjoyed PoE 1 and PoE 2, though its not isometric. The combat animation is excellent, the landscape very detailed and colorful. The story line was well written and builds upon its predecessors, though I wish they had voiced the main character. I don't have a monitor and I'm using a low cost Walmart TV, so I get some tearing occasionally. Overall I thought it was a great game.

Its not perfect by any means, but hell yeah i a lot of fun with that!
Especially exploration and combat are top notch.

I really want to love this game, but it runs so poorly even on a good gaming PC that its not worth the cost. Hopefully the devs choose to do some optimisation. This is the only UE5 game my PC struggles with.

While I am enjoying the game, I will state some reasons that are making me not want to play.

1 - The physics are wacky, making even slight movements extremely jarring while holding anything that doesn't weigh six metric tons.

2 - The Huntsman is a time waster who will randomly shoot or walk in your direction for no reason. My favourite is when he randomly runs through the halls in your direction when you have made no noise.

3 - The Clown is a piece of shit that will kick your cart for no reason, and if you're hiding right next to it, will then kick you.

4 - The Trudge is ridiculous. Bastard grabbed my cart, destroying it and everything inside...on LEVEL 1!

5 - I don't like how precise I have to be to grab Gnomes. There should also not be some invisible timer on the effectiveness of your grab either. The Overcharge should NOT apply to Gnomes and Bombs.

6 - Vases are way too delicate, like, impossibly so. It was fun while it lasted, but this should be patched out. Vases should not break from the slightest movement.

7 - The Ducky is the most annoying sack of shit I have ever experienced in a video game, ever. So great that the Duck Bucket is locked to multiplayer or until you have at least 3 DJs.

8 - Melee weapons needing to be charged is stupid. Guns and electronics I understand, but melee weapons (outside of the Taser Stick) should not require charging.

------------------------------------------

Suggestions:

1 - The Huntsman should have progression to his action, not just instant aggression upon hearing a single noise in your direction. Also, he shouldn't attack you for hitting him with anything. Treating the object as a part of you while using telekinesis is silly. Unless the Huntsman is a Telekit, how would he know it was you specifically?

2 - The Clown should not be allowed to simply kick the cart and destroy everything like a toddler that can't get its way. Not unless you're moving it or it is kicking and the cart happens to be in the way. It sucks that you can spend 10-15 minutes gathering treasure, only for some deranged, mutated molester to blow it all up.

3 - Continuing the theme of ridiculous mobs, I believe that the Trudge should be reserved for higher levels (Level 7 onwards). In fact the game should scale it's difficulty based on the number of players. So, one player could see the difficulty go up slowly over time, while a team of four are immediately in the thick of it. A single player should not get 3-4 enemies on Level 1.

4 - Instead of using crystals to recharge melee weapons, there could be a repair station at each shop that costs $2K-$10K (and should cap at 10K per weapon after level 10). Melee weapons, in my opinion, should no longer be rechargeable, and have a set amount of uses; once they're used up, the weapon breaks and you have to buy it again. However, with the repair station, you could prolong the use of melee weapons by restoring uses (but there could be drawbacks like 2% degradation per repair).

This would make buying crystals worth the cost because they wouldn't need to be constantly replaced.

5 - Overcharge should scale to the number of players VS Level. No need to get rid of it, but it could be less apparent for a single player early on and then ramp-up over time as you progress through Levels.

-------------------------------

From what I can see, the devs are doing the exact same thing as the Helldivers II devs did (i.e., make the game barely playable through a bunch of needless "updates" and nerfs).

You can always tell when devs don't play their own games. If they do, it is always while using console commands in dev mode.

At this point I cannot recommend this game if you want a fun single player experience, since it's currently scaled for multiplayer across the board. But I will also not tell people avoid the game as it is fun in multiplayer.

1. enemies pathing is kinda sus.
even if you're not making any sound, just hiding below anything. you'll see enemy keep patrolling near you. and by near you, I mean they would loops back and fort in front of you 2x or 3x at minimum before going of somewhere. from what I see, certain enemies shown this behavior more than others, with the biggest offender being the headman and gunman.

2. end (go back to the truck) time enemies instant spawn is bullshit.
why the fuck the enemy that died in this time literally ALWAYS spawning in the NEXT ROOM? (very observable with gnomes and skullbombs especially when playing solo). this make a problem of endless gnome and or skulls trapping player(s) to death easily. 

3. a certain map suck.
yes, I'm talking about headman manor.
is there reason why a manor of someone with that huge size of a head to have "normal" size door? 
those doors are stupid game design and just made moving big things harder than necessary, even close to impossible at times combined with how narrow the hallway is.

4. the current beta version

health pack patch do quite hurt. but eh.

What I Like:
Repo is one of the most fun games I have played in a while! The pure chaos that can happen anytime brings me back to why horror games can be fun. And to experience that with friends is a crazy experience. I personally love going through high-stress level situations with others. I see newer sides of people, laughed, got scared. I adore this game. As I love a challenge now and then- I look forward to trying to overcome level after level as we face harder monsters and get outnumbered.

What I Dislike:
Because this game can be very challenging, there will be moments of frustration and disappointment. Some situations feel impossible while others probably could be helped if we had known better. That is all part of the process in improvement. Remember, try to play for fun more than trying to win. You can't win in this game as it is an endless play. I do hope more updates are on the way, more maps are being made, and maybe checkpoints would ease the idea of losing it all.

Recommend it?:
I highly recommend trying out this game! I came in not expecting much but after some convincing from friends and their excitement playing it, I do not regret coming back.


Overall:
For an affordable game that doesn't other much but stupid fun, get it. Try it at least. This game makes it on one of my favorites.

R.E.P.O. est un jeu de survie où vous devez naviguer dans un monde dévasté, rempli de dangers et de mystères. Vous incarnez un personnage qui doit non seulement survivre, mais aussi comprendre ce qui a causé l'effondrement de la société. Le mélange de gestion de ressources, exploration et survie intense crée une atmosphère captivante.

Points forts :

Ambiance immersive et atmosphérique.

Gameplay de survie tendu avec une gestion des ressources captivante.

Un scénario intrigant et mystérieux à découvrir.

Points faibles :

Quelques bugs mineurs et problèmes de performance.

Certaines mécaniques peuvent sembler répétitives sur le long terme.

Конвейер по производству кооперативных “экстракшен-хорроров” не думает сбавлять обороты. Вслед за игрой про репортёров Headliners выходит REPO и тут же собирает огромную кассу и высокий онлайн. Но что в игре такого особенного и прорывного? Трезво оценивая геймплей, могу сказать, что эта игра - просто расхайпленный стримерами проект, который можно назвать улучшенной версией Lethal Company. 
Геймплей, как и положено такой игре, сводится к поиску ценностей на уровне, их продаже и покупке улучшений. С каждым завершённым уровнем растёт сложность и квота на собранные вещи. 

? Забавная идея с роботами, которые комично бегают, падают, вращают глазами и открывают рот в такт тому, что игроки говорят через голосовую связь. Собственно, как мне кажется, на этих забавных роботах и держатся все продажи игры. 
? Есть подробная карта, которая выручает и не даёт заблудиться в лабиринтах. 
? Погибших игроков можно воскресить, если притащить их головы на оценочную платформу. 
? Нет таймера на прохождение. 
? Необычная механика с перетаскиванием вещей, которые могут повредиться и потерять ценность при ударе. То же касается и других интерактивных предметов, типа оружия. 
? Большое разнообразие вещей для сбора. 
? Поддержка модов. 

? Игра очень “душная”: 
?? Монстры должны вызывать у игроков страх, но они вызывают только возмущение. Зачастую, вражеские создания просто перекрывают единственный проход до нужной комнаты и приходится сидеть в укромном уголке, ожидая несколько минут, пока ситуация не станет безопасной.  Некоторые монстры появляются прямо перед носом и подолгу остаются в соседних комнатах.  
?? Вы не можете победить в игре, поскольку уровни бесконечные. Но это не проблема. Проблема в том, что ваши старания и апгрейды ничего не значат - вас просто задавят увеличивающимся количеством монстров, с которыми вы ничего не сможете сделать, если у вас закончился ограниченный запас гранат и выстрелов из транквилизатора.  
Некоторые монстры ломают лут, что может привести к провалу миссии. 
?? Проблемы доставляет и сам левел дизайн - после седьмого уровня растёт количество ям и узких проходов, которые зачастую не менее опасны, чем местные обитатели. 

Игра весёлая, но только в кампании людей. Чем больше вы играете, тем меньше смешных и необычных ситуаций происходит, а вот раздражение от игры растёт. За свою цену, контента здесь достаточно. Если вы наигрались в Lethal company, но хочется чего-то подобного, то REPO - лучший вариант.

O jogo Repo é uma experiência cativante que mescla mecanicas inovadoras com uma narrativa envolvente, oferecendo aos jogadores uma jornada única, repleta de decis?es morais, desafios estratégicos e ambienta??es imersivas. Desde os primeiros minutos de gameplay, é evidente o cuidado dos desenvolvedores em criar um universo coeso, onde cada elemento visual, sonoro e mecanico contribui para a constru??o de uma atmosfera intrigante e provocadora.

Um dos maiores destaques de Repo é sua premissa original. Ao invés de recorrer a fórmulas convencionais, o jogo opta por uma narrativa centrada em um futuro distópico onde agentes de recupera??o precisam confiscar bens de cidad?os inadimplentes. Essa abordagem oferece n?o apenas uma perspectiva diferente do conceito de herói, mas também proporciona uma reflex?o crítica sobre sistemas econ?micos, desigualdade e o papel da autoridade. O jogador é confrontado com decis?es difíceis, muitas vezes tendo que escolher entre seguir ordens ou agir com empatia ― o que adiciona camadas de profundidade moral à experiência.

O design de jogo é inteligentemente construído para refor?ar essa tens?o narrativa. As miss?es s?o variadas, cada uma com seus próprios dilemas e obstáculos. As mecanicas de infiltra??o, persuas?o e combate s?o bem balanceadas, permitindo diferentes abordagens aos desafios. Isso confere ao jogador liberdade para explorar seu estilo de jogo preferido, seja por meio da furtividade, diálogo estratégico ou a??o direta. Essa versatilidade aumenta a rejogabilidade do título, já que cada partida pode seguir caminhos distintos.

Visualmente, Repo apresenta uma dire??o artística marcante. Os cenários urbanos decadentes, os interiores das habita??es e os trajes dos personagens refor?am o clima de opress?o e decadência social. A paleta de cores, composta por tons frios e ilumina??o sombria, contribui para criar uma atmosfera densa, quase claustrofóbica ― condizente com a realidade dos personagens que o jogo retrata. A qualidade gráfica é impressionante, e o cuidado com os detalhes é evidente, desde os p?steres nas paredes até as express?es faciais dos NPCs.

A trilha sonora é outro ponto alto. As composi??es musicais, ora minimalistas, ora tensas, acompanham perfeitamente o ritmo do jogo. Os efeitos sonoros s?o imersivos, ajudando a construir tens?o nos momentos certos. O silêncio também é bem utilizado, servindo como ferramenta narrativa para intensificar o impacto emocional de determinadas cenas. Isso demonstra maturidade no design sonoro e compreens?o do papel do áudio na experiência imersiva do jogador.

O roteiro de Repo é sólido, com diálogos bem escritos e personagens com motiva??es críveis. Mesmo os NPCs secundários s?o bem desenvolvidos, o que contribui para o realismo do universo do jogo. O protagonista, que pode ser moldado pelas escolhas do jogador, tem um arco narrativo interessante, evoluindo conforme as decis?es tomadas ao longo da campanha. Esse elemento de personaliza??o narrativa garante que os jogadores se sintam parte da história, ao invés de simples espectadores.

Outro ponto positivo é a interface de usuário, que é limpa, intuitiva e funcional. O HUD fornece as informa??es necessárias sem poluir a tela, e os menus s?o de fácil navega??o. Isso facilita o engajamento contínuo, sem que o jogador se sinta perdido ou sobrecarregado por comandos desnecessários.

Em termos de desempenho técnico, Repo se destaca por sua estabilidade. Durante os testes, n?o foram observados bugs significativos ou quedas de desempenho, o que demonstra o cuidado com o polimento do produto final. A otimiza??o permite que o jogo rode bem em diferentes configura??es de hardware, tornando-o acessível a uma base maior de jogadores. Além disso, o suporte pós-lan?amento, com atualiza??es regulares e respostas ativas da equipe de desenvolvimento, mostra o compromisso com a comunidade.

A comunidade, inclusive, é vibrante e engajada. Fóruns e redes sociais têm sido palco de discuss?es profundas sobre as escolhas morais do jogo, bem como teorias sobre seu enredo. Essa intera??o entre jogadores amplia a experiência para além da tela, refor?ando o impacto cultural de Repo.

O modo de progress?o do jogo também é bem pensado. A evolu??o de habilidades, equipamentos e relacionamentos com outros personagens é fluida e recompensadora. O jogador sente que suas a??es têm consequências concretas no mundo do jogo, o que aumenta o envolvimento emocional e estratégico. A dificuldade é bem calibrada, oferecendo desafios progressivos sem se tornar frustrante.

Em resumo, Repo é um exemplo de como um jogo pode unir entretenimento e crítica social de forma inteligente. Seu universo rico, jogabilidade envolvente e aten??o aos detalhes fazem dele uma experiência memorável. é um título que consegue ser impactante tanto no nível mecanico quanto emocional, permanecendo na mente dos jogadores mesmo após o término da campanha.

Com sua abordagem corajosa e inovadora, Repo se posiciona como uma das obras mais interessantes do cenário atual dos games. é um jogo que respeita a inteligência do jogador, instiga reflex?es e proporciona horas de gameplay de alta qualidade. Не надо бить камнями, я сейчас объясню, почему я СЕЙЧАС не рекомендую эту игру.
Знаю, что она ещё не доработана, много каких ещё вещей изменится и т.п. Но уже есть вещи, которые просто вымораживают. Да даже иногда задаёшься вопросом "что курили разработчики, когда добавляли ЭТО".
1. Гномы. Они слишком сильны, потому что:
Они сносят 10 ХП игроку
Они сносят предметы
Их сразу появляется 4, а на поздних этапах так вообще по 12 могут быть, и *разбирайся* с этим как хоти
Внутри игровая стоимость - 1 тир, т.е. спам может быть уже на 3 уровне 
Время респауна их - 3-5 минут (в отличие от других, 8-15 мин)
Решение: добавить в алгоритм спавна лимит 2 и не более одних и тех же монстров, перевод гномов в 2 тир, а взрывашек - в 1 тир (естественно, поменять значение ХП), урезание урона в 2 раза гномам
2. Механика спавна монстров после завершения финальной точки сбора. Они появляются моментально. Даже гномы.
Решение: добавить 2-минутный таймер после смерти монстра
3. "Мусорность" некоторых предметов. Колба красная, радио, контейнер для химикатов, колба оранжевая - их всех объединяет большой размер на относительно плохую стоимость.
Решение: хз, тут трудно придумать что-нибудь.
4. В последующем будущем - механика перегрева. Тут наверно стоит немного объяснить, почему это плохо.
Есть условно два типа игроков lategame: те, кто швыряют монстров в ямы, об потолок, и те, кто расстреливает их. И то, и другое хорошо, да и цена таких тактик хорошо сбалансирована: на силу примерно 200к тратишь + примерно 60к на дальность луча, и максимум к 6 лвл будет 12 силы. Дробовик, хоть и дешевле, всё же требует энергию, поэтому ценник в арифметической прогрессии растёт, так что примерно так-же получается к 6-7 лвл по затратам. Да и сила в целом нужна, надо как-то тяжёлые предметы таскать.
Но тут механика перегрева появляется... Знали бы, как она руинит всё. Разработчики буквально обрезают один из способов, причём самый надёжный, но при этом довольно опасный. Дробовик не рассчитан, чтобы массово расправляться с монстрами.
Да и признаемся, после 10 лвл начинается резня монстров, от этого не избежать: игра сама подстрекает на уничтожение монстров.
Решение: сбалансировать перегрев, чтобы работал только на монстров 3-го тира и некоторых 2-го + времени немного требовалось для перегрева + зависел от того, сколько силы у персонажа. Т.е., если есть монстр с требование силы 4, но при этом сила вкачана на 8, то перегрев должен быть оооооооочень медленным, или вообще отсутствовать. Это ещё более-менее оставляет тактику "швыряц монстров, чтобы получить деньги" работоспособной, но при это требования ещё больше + меньше эффективности с относительно малой силой. К примеру, с 13 силой поднимаешь клоуна, через 5-8 секунд перегрев. С 18 поднимаешь того же клоуна - 24-38 секунд до перегрева.

The game is pretty great some of the time, but another good bit of the time the game is just annoying and frustrating. I have only played the game at low levels but the beginning should be the strongest part or just as good as the rest of the game.
Early game problem 1: Whenever there's a monster around the game becomes a waiting simulator. By far the best way to deal with enemies until you get expensive weapons and stamina or health upgrades is to just hide under something when you see them, and sometimes change hiding spot. There's nothing really tense or scary after the first time dealing with an enemy, because the solution to surviving enemies ends up being the same for basically all of them. The game feels like it wants to be a cool abandoned world exploration game where you recover valuables, and it also wants the game to have some danger to it, but it doesn't quite know how to have that danger. Lethal company doesn't have this problem because even at low levels when you're probably gonna die to most creatures you encounter, not only is it still funny to encounter them quite often but since you can't hide in a safe place as soon as you see something, the game has tons more tension and feels more like a game. Also dying just completely sucks, deaths in this game aren't funny like in lethal company or content warning, and doing nothing while your living teammates are waiting for a monster to finally leave them alone feels like having your two 30 second ads buffer for 4 minutes straight.
Early game problem 2: The enemies are just annoying to deal with. This is similar to problem 1 but even when not hiding, not only do the enemies not at all feel grounded in the game's world (Lethal company makes all of its enemies feel like their presence is logical, and content warning, despite also having very eclectic and wacky enemies, also makes it feel like the monsters present could exist). The frog chef, murderous duck, old man with a shotgun, giant ceiling eye, flying head, and scarecrow thing do not feel like they should all be in the same game or at least there should be greater separation between those enemies. Very often (and it may just be that I'm bad but still it's always frustrating) a monster will come along and just damage the items in the cart or whatever high value items we couldn't manage to get in the cart. Good enemy design pushes players away from a certain bad play style, but the enemies here all feel like they're punishing me for playing this game. The rugrats are just bad and should not be at low levels, if they're supposed to punish players who leave the cart far away from them then it fails to do that because they always just run up to the cart while my team is already there and start breaking our things without us being able to do anything.
The game does not give very much catharsis at low levels, there's occasionally the ability to kill a single enemy but that rarely happens, and the big number for money at the end of each trip feels small compared to the item prices in the shop.

Наверное лучшее что я играл после Леталки, реально крутая игра, у игры большой потенциал, страшные монстры, интересные карты и в целом каждая карта имеет прикольную атмосферу, нравится что в игре можно и побояться и посмеяться с некоторых моментов, определенно стоит своих денег (особенно если тебе очень понравилась Lethal Company), всем рекомендую.

I'll go against the "overwhelmingly positive" grain and say I don't like this game. 

It's overly unforgiving in the sense that you get one shot to make quota -- this takes the "fun goofiness" that I enjoy with my friends in other quota-based games like Lethal Company, Headliners out of the game because one misstep means you're dead and you're right back to start. I can understand some people enjoying that (it's hardcore) but I wish there were options for lower stakes -- custom lobby settings that give you extra chances, etc. I prefer casual play.

While the game has fun ideas like the text to speech, items and movement mechanics, it has some glaring issues that ultimately make it not really fun to play:

- no time limit means that if you die you are stuck spectating for a good while, so I ended up alt-tabbing often and doing something else

- monsters are not really fun to play against nor scary (unless they spawn right behind a door). Most of the time you end up crouching under a couch and waiting for them to leave, which sometimes might take a few minutes or longer if they keep looping around the area

- too few ways to go around. If an enemy spawns in a hallway and there's no alternative way to progress you are stuck waiting for them to despawn (see point above)

- base stamina is pretty low and takes way too long to recharge

- the zoomer emoji based humor should just be removed, I don't even know if zoomers themselves enjoy it

This game is amazing! Anyways here is the definition of grass!

Grass is a type of plant with narrow leaves growing from the base. Their appearance as a common plant was in the mid-Cretaceous period. There are 12,000 species now.[3]

A common kind of grass is used to cover the ground in places such as lawns and parks. Grass is usually the color green. That is because they are wind-pollinated rather than insect-pollinated, so they do not have to attract insects. Green is the best color for photosynthesis.

Grasslands such as savannah and prairie are where grasses are dominant. They cover 40.5% of the land area of the Earth, but not Greenland and Antarctica.[4]

Grasses are monocotyledon herbaceous plants. They include the "grass" of the family Poaceae, which are called grass by ordinary people. This family is also called the Gramineae and includes some of the sedges (Cyperaceae) and the rushes (Juncaceae).[5] These three families are not very closely related, though all of them belong to clades in the order Poales. They are similar adaptations to a similar life-style.

With about 780 genera and about 12,000 species,[3] the Poaceae is the fifth-largest plant family. Only the Asteraceae, Orchidaceae, Fabaceae and Rubiaceae have more species.[6]

The true grasses include cereals, bamboo and the grasses of lawns (turf) and grassland. Uses for graminoids include food (as grain, shoots or rhizomes), drink (beer, whisky), pasture for livestock, thatch, paper, fuel, clothing, insulation, construction, basket weaving and many others.

Many grasses are short, but some grasses can grow tall, such as bamboo. Plants from the grass family can grow in many places and make grasslands, including areas that are very dry or cold. There are several other plants that look similar to grass and are referred to as such but are not members of the grass family. These plants include rushes, reeds, papyrus and water chestnut. Seagrass is a monocot in the order Alismatales.

Grasses are an important food for many animals, such as deer, buffalo, cattle, mice, grasshoppers, caterpillars and many other grazers. Unlike other plants, grasses grow from the bottom, so when animals eat grass, they usually do not destroy the part that grows.[7] This is part of the reason why the plants are so successful.

Without grass, more soil might wash away into rivers (erosion).

Evolution of grass
Grasses include some of the most versatile plant life-forms. They became widespread toward the end of the Cretaceous. Fossilized dinosaur dung (coprolites) have been found containing grass phytoliths (silica stones inside grass leaves).[8] Grasses have adapted to conditions in lush rain forests, dry deserts, cold mountains and even intertidal habitats, and are now the most widespread plant type. Grass is a valuable source of food and energy for many animals.[9]

Grass and people
Lawn grass is often planted on sports fields and in the area around a building. Sometimes chemicals and water is used to help lawns to grow.

People have used grasses for a long time. People eat parts of grasses. Corn, wheat, barley, oats, rice and millet are cereals, common grains whose seeds are used for food and to make alcohol such as beer.

Sugar comes from sugar cane, which is also a plant in the grass family. People have grown grasses as food for farm animals for about 4,000 years. People use bamboo to build houses, fences, furniture and other things. Grass plants can also be used as fuel, to cover rooves, and to weave baskets.

Language
In English, the word "grass" appears in several phrases. For example:

"The grass is always greener on the other side" means "people are never happy with what they have and want something else".
"Don't let the grass grow under your feet" means "Do something".
"A snake in the grass" is about a person that will not be honest and will trick others.
All flesh is grass: Old Testament book of Isaiah, chapter 40, verses 6C8. A very true observation of the present-day ecology. See the Miocene for the ecological relevance.
Grass is a slang term for cannabis (pot, weed, or marijuana). Cannabis looks like a grass, but it is actually a rosid.

游戏整体评价：
游戏很不错，单人玩的很爽，多人玩的也很开心，我也很可能会继续玩下去，解决了我的游戏养胃，一个人也能无敌于天下。
恐怖程度：
没有封面那么恐怖，其实看惯了过后大多数怪还是挺慈眉善目的（除了小矮人，伤害不高，纯烦人）喜欢暗区突围那样的游戏，这个就包对你胃口.
整体玩法介绍：
进地图，把一切能搬走的都搬上车，躲避或击杀怪物的同时把物品推到提交点卖钱，然后购买物资提升自己后开启下一轮循环。推荐3人一队（最多六人，打mod可以更多），延迟不高也欢乐。

bug如下
多人的情况下有概率卡出全物品bug，（触发方式：拿着未结账的手雷进车中，在发动车子的时候引爆有概率触发）触发后会把游戏拥有的所有武器，血包，无人机和加成都刷在车上。概率很高。

单人商店购买提交点无法打开（触发方式，在进入商店前，在提取器升起之前按下按钮，就能百分百卡住）触发表现为提取器无法升上去，再按按钮也不动如山（解决方式：重启该存档）

怪物追击仇恨无法甩掉（触发方式就是大头，在桌下拉一下它，然后躲在大圆桌下，它会卡在桌子边缘无法动弹，并一直怪叫，在你离开桌子后不再卡住，直追你而来）具体表现就是追到死，不管跑了多远，跨了多少房价，藏在何处都会追杀。


新手帮助：
天赋加点方面：力量提升最优先(到4级以后就能拿起大多数物品)，其次买体力和冲刺速度，多段跳等其他加成按需提升
武器推荐：
前期：采购手榴弹，爆炸地雷等，小丑玩偶点三次鼻子也能当炸弹用（大多数怪一发秒，但是大锤不行，得两颗）
后期；麻醉最优先，枪、霰弹枪其次，近战武器整活可以，玩冲击手榴弹和冲击地雷不推荐。

无人机推荐
不会玩，建议就暂时不买，多了解一下怪物。
后面可以单独击杀怪物后，首推充电无人机（卡武器的无限子弹用），其次无敌无人机，其他的都按你的需求去购买使用
血包不用买，结账完成后，拿着血包上车，点击开车后手持血包狂按e按键有概率使用到。


通用守则：
1.大多数怪物在你离开其视线4-5秒会安分下来（除了鸭子固定10秒）

2.躲在桌下所有怪物基本都能无视你（如果你在躲藏前被怪物看到，在你逃往下一个房间之前，是躲藏不了的）

3.提交点把死亡队友的头一起提交可以复活队友，复活的队友只有1滴血。

4,提交点内的物品不要超出提交点范围，下落的提取器会把东西压坏。

5.在提交完所有的提交点后，怪物的刷新会变的非常快，如果该局有小矮人，爆炸骷髅头等小型怪物，小心被围攻。又因为这种特性，请在最后一个提交点提交完成之前，赶紧跑回车上（最后一个提交点建议留一个离车最近的点，车进去不要等结算马上开跑）

6.第2-3关为两个提交点，4-5关为3个，6关开始为四个提交点。

7.城堡的炼药锅可以油炸小鸭子，利用它会追随准心的特性，将它骗到锅里，一小会就会炸倒它。如果你这样做了，请追上去，趁它还在7秒硬直，拿起它然后尝试摔死它，如果没能成功它会马上狂暴，没有力量的炸倒它后等狂暴过去再进行一次以上操作，就能拿舍利子（怪物死亡掉落的高价值物品）了。

8.冷知识：联机人越多，房间就越卡。

9.提交点提交价值超过要求的部分会结算成钱袋，而钱袋的大小是不同的，超过1k以内是小号，5k以内中号.8k以上是大号钱袋，所以比较贪的玩法就是，把所有值钱的东西放一个提取点交，超出的部分不管再多都可以压缩成一个大号钱袋子，能最大程度的赚钱。

10.每一次商店购物，天花板上都可以找到暗房，里面会有便宜的武器，人类手榴弹2k，集束手雷2k，可以利用无重力无人机，羽翼无人机，跳起来按Q就能一个人上去，冲击手榴弹也可以跳上去，拉开引信后放置在地上，在一定的时机跳起并按Q就能上去。如果是联机进行游戏，可以蹲下让队友把你举上去。

11.进入游戏后马上改设置，具体操作可以去bilibili看设置该如何改，最重要的是改按键说话，不然乱出声音会被怪物发现。还有画面，可以按照自己最舒服的画质去调，调清晰。

12.很多萌新不知道汉化包怎么下，移步去哔哩哔哩搜教程，汉化包是免费的，不要花钱买

An incredibly fun game.

It takes the Lethal Company formula and fixes most of its problems: you can actually hide from monsters, you can fight and kill them, you don't always get one-shotted, you can respawn mid-round, transporting loot is made fun and challenging and not simply a chore, maps are no longer just a collection of empty rooms with some useless furniture scattered around ― and there is so, SO much more.

If you liked Lethal Company you will love this game; if you never tried Lethal, instead, now it's a good time to pick up the genre and have fun with your friends

Man, what a game. I have had fun playing it with friends, fun playing it with family, even fun playing it by myself. I love REPO. Something about a proximity chat horror game with a good physics engine just scratches my brain the right way. Had so many great moments running bits with my friends, many of which end with us turning a corner and being blasted by the shotgun of a blind old man. Whats not to love?

game_name: Like a Dragon: Pirate Yakuza in Hawaii
Like a Dragon: Pirate Yakuza in Hawaii
review:
A bit underwhelming in places, but still a solid game. Combat is fluid, but not as good as Judgment or even Gaiden. PC Port also had a fair bit of issues, though some have been fixed in patches.

Story is nothing special. It can be summarized as 'Majima loses his memory, becomes a Pirate, looks for treasure, finds the treasure, beats up the bad guys, everybody gets a happy ending'. Music also didn't stand out as much compared to Gaiden or Infinite Wealth.

It's definitely a weaker spinoff, with odd pacing here and there, but still worth trying out, especially if you wanna see more Majima, and have finished Infinite Wealth.

I am not a golf fan, but this game got me pretty hooked on playing golf. I know it's not to everyone's tastes, but I am not disappointed with my time spend vs money.
golf

Pros:
The game is hard, which makes it fun (Pro or harder with difficult conditions). I like the fact that I'm not winning every tournament by 10+ strokes. I have some tournaments where my game is on and I win by 8 strokes and I have other tournaments where my game is off and I lose by 8 strokes. The input bias, in my opinion, is a great addition to the game as it makes your swing more difficult and you really have to concentrate. I haven't played any online tournaments, this is just based off career mode. 

Cons:
It takes a while to get enough coins to upgrade your player. I don't think the upgrading should be incredibly fast, but it does feel a bit too slow. Rivals just needs to be removed or revamped. I have yet to have a rivalry actually be close (even on Master difficulty). I just beat Finau by 7 strokes because he was +7 in the tournament. The rivalries feel forced and do not add anything to the game because they aren't actually competitive. Sponsorships are annoying. After every single tournament, you have to go through 3 sponsors and accept or decline. It takes WAY too long to progress through sponsorships. They don't add anything to the game. If anything, they should just get rid of sponsorships, add some sort of currency that you get from tournaments, and then let you buy clubs and clothes with that currency. Finally, interviews, just get rid of them. They are unnecessary in all sports games.

In madden i was to 10% in any shooter im top of the leader boards. I put 200 hours into this game to lose like this? if you dont land 2 feet from the pin you lose. something fishy is going on going -22 on legend consistently is absolutely impossible

So first off, I'm gonna start by saying/agreeing with the community that 2K pulled some really shady stuff during the launch of this game with the leveling system.  I won't beat a dead horse, if you're reading this review, you've already read 100 others that complain about the slow leveling.  Sure, its excessive, but people who say that you HAVE to buy VC in order to advance are not being truthful, this can be grinded like any other game. 

I didn't buy early access, i did buy the clubhouse pass, more for the free evo-tools than anything....just hit 115 hours in the game, and lets face it, probably 10-15 hours have been spent asleep in my chair after a long night of playing/drinking.  
My main, technician, just hit 99...i also have greenskeeper, sculptor, and powerhouse to 85...magician ill get around to eventually.  But never played more than 2 rounds with any of them, and never purchased VC.

There are ways to do the challenges and amass huge amounts of VC...if you're creative.  Problem is...people want to play one season of career, or 10 rounds online and be 99 ovr, thats the society we live in.  Need 400 yard drives? play back 9 marigot.  Need career putt distance?  Aim approach shots so they land 50ish feet away, that way if/when you make the putts, you'll be working towards putt distance, and all the long range putting challenges.  Need crazy scores/eagles/albatrosses or just really fast rounds?  Red Tees!  But nah...don't get creative, just whine about it.

In terms of this actually being a golf game, i've been a huge fan of that other garbage franchise (the one that used to have tiger woods) for 30 years, and i think PGA 2k25 is way better than that game.  More of a simulation, but not as brutal as 2k23 was.  Its great for a round with friends, or to play a quick round online, character creation has also been vastly improved in this years game.

Nutshell : New/potentially new players, don't be turned off by all the naysayers...but don't buy VC either!  It can all be accomplished with a little brainpower and elbow grease.

Refunded because the in-game economy is downright predatory, where the only way to reasonably level up your own character is to either grind for hours (not fun) or pay real money (insulting).

No-one should buy a game that expects players to pay real money to have fun playing the game WHEN THE GAME IS ALSO AAA FULL PRICE - this is probably why they're shutting down the older titles online modes, so they can force people onto predatory games they can make money from.
Il y a beaucoup de problème de connection quand on souhaite joué en matchmaking avec un ami ! "le matchmaking a été interompu.

This game is awesome because it showed me how much of a degen I was being, living in my addiction of this game. Pay to win game tisk tisk. Now I play real golf out of spite because I know I'll get more consistent rewards for my efforts, instead of some algorithm determining how much fun I'm allowed to have. The game is not consistent enough for it to be fun, making it not worth grinding, unless you are someone who needs validation from just spending money in order to win. I'm giving this game a thumbs up for being the best weight loss program on the market today. I've lost over 20lbs now that I actually play golf in real life, I have a nice car and a hot girlfriend. Thanks PGA Tour 2K25! Keep making games like this and society will be better because of it. 6/10

For the first 56 hours I very much enjoyed this game. For the last 2 hours, which really in turn is multiple days in which I attempted to play, this game has been completely broken. Backswing animation locks constantly. Load up the game, first shot, character animation locks in the backswing and the rest of the game is still running. Force close and repeat. Completely unplayable. Hopefully the upcoming season update fixes this but it's 2k so I doubt it.
Solid improvement over 2k23 (which was still good). Not a fan of the VC system, but if you ignore that and just focus on the rest of the game, its worth it.

game_name: A Game About Digging A Hole
review:
[h1]Рецензия на игру ?A Game About Digging A Hole?[/h1]  
[b]Оценка:[/b] 7/10  

[h2]Обзор[/h2]  
Минималистичный симулятор, предлагающий механику копания ямы в саду купленного дома. Основной цикл строится на добыче ресурсов, их продаже для улучшения инструментов и постепенном погружении вглубь земли.  

[h2]Ключевые аспекты[/h2]  
[list]  
[*][b]Геймплей:[/b] Цикл ?копание → сбор ресурсов → улучшение оборудования? создаёт ощущение прогресса на ранних этапах. Поздние стадии характеризуются рутиной из-за частых возвратов на поверхность.  
[*][b]Техническая реализация:[/b] Простая графика с яркой палитрой, ненавязчивое звуковое сопровождение, интуитивное управление. Столкновения с окружением и отсутствие приседа усложняют маневрирование.  
[*][b]Стоимость:[/b] ￡3.99 за 2C4 часа контента ― соответствует бюджетным инди-проектам, но низкая реиграбельность снижает ценность.  
[/list]  

[h2]Критические замечания[/h2]  
[list]  
[*]Отсутствие нарратива: нет сюжета или персонажей, только абстрактная цель.  
[*]Дисбаланс механик: необходимость мониторинга батареи и здоровья становится раздражающим фактором.  
[*]Ограниченный креатив: невозможность альтернативных способов исследования (например, строительства лестниц).  
[/list]  

[h2]Целевая аудитория[/h2]  
[list]  
[*]Поклонники расслабляющего геймплея без давления (аналоги: Powerwash Simulator).  
[*]Те, кто ценит прозрачные цели и краткие игровые сессии.  
[*]Искатели нишевых инди-экспериментов за символическую цену.  
[/list]  

[h2]Заключение[/h2]  
Проект успешно реализует заявленную идею, но не выходит за её рамки. Сильные стороны ― медитативный геймплей и доступная цена ― нивелируются ограниченным контентом и механическим гриндингом.  
[b]Рекомендация:[/b] Приобретать на распродажах или для целенаправленного релаксационного опыта.

game_name: A Game About Digging A Hole
review:
Game Review: Digging a Hole  
Rating: 4.5/5

"Digging a Hole" is a surprisingly captivating game that combines simple mechanics with addictive gameplay. The core concept is straightforward: dig into the earth, discover hidden ores, and upgrade your tools to go even deeper. As you make progress, you unlock exciting gear like a jetpack and a powerful drill, which open up new possibilities and make exploration more thrilling.

What makes the game truly interesting is how it balances simplicity with a sense of progression. The minimalist design keeps things easy to understand, making it accessible for all players, but the thrill of uncovering rare ores and upgrading your equipment creates a compelling loop that keeps you hooked. The visuals are charming and minimalistic, perfectly matching the relaxed yet engaging atmosphere.

While "Digging a Hole" is wonderfully straightforward, its simplicity might feel limiting for those seeking complex mechanics or a deep storyline. Nonetheless, its elegant design and satisfying upgrade system make it a highly enjoyable experience for casual gamers and explorers alike.

Overall, "Digging a Hole" offers a delightful blend of simplicity and fun, making it a must-play for anyone looking for a relaxing yet engaging game. Rating: 4.5 out of 5.

game_name: A Game About Digging A Hole
review:
This is the game I wanted 13 years ago when Minecraft released on Xbox 360. Every child yearns to turn the backyard into a crater, and this game satisfies that primal calling.

Or at the very least, this is a good stepping stone that another dev team might cash in on. What I really want is a longer game on a greater scale with more progression. Took me 5 hours to erase the backyard, and I want a game that will add a couple of zeros to that figure.

Sworn is very fun with friends or solo, and the team seems to really be working hard on making it even better. It's a Hades clone, but with great multiplayer and some really unique features that make it worth playing.
SWORN is a great co-op with beautiful art graphics, and enjoyable soundtrack and plenty of replay ability. It is very hard and frustrating to finish solo, unless you're hardcore.

A wonderful experience, having a blast playing this with my significant other. In many ways this game RIPS a lot of things from Hades, basically entirely and in that sense it's cheap, but the experience of playing with others is such a unique and fun time. 

I think the game is playable and a great time right now and its still early access. Should only get better.
divertido, mas falta coisa ainda

Game has been fun so far but the disconnects in coop are very annoying. Losing out on progress because you DC right at the end feels awful. Until the game is fixed for coop in that regard, I can't recommend it to anyone if you're playing coop. 

However, if you're playing solo you'll probably find some enjoyment. The combat is very inspired by Hades so if you like that style of gameplay, you'll have some fun with this one. The story isn't as compelling and the lack of voice acting on the Gods- I mean Fae is noticeable. Still, I think it has potential for growth so it's worth keeping an eye at the very least.

Nice game, reminds one of Hades (game play wise as well as gaphics). Coop is a nice touch, but could have been done better (there are no synergy attacks or the likes). Difficulty is good (from fairly easy to neigh on impossible). In 70 hours I have had one two game breaking bugs, but lag was a problem once in a while though I am not sure if this was game related or an internet issue. Anyway, I recommand it, solo as well as coop.

Ya en Early Access está bastante completo la verdad, le metí muchisimas horas tanto al primer Hades como también la segunda entrega y puedo decir que de verdad este juego es muy bueno, si tienes oportunidad de probarlo hazlo y si te gustan los juegos de este genero no te vas a arrepentir.

Le jeu est de pire en pire. L'équilibrage ? qu'es ce que c'est ? Vous serez heureux de voir le signe de certains dieux ;) les hitboxs sont frustrantes, les taux de drop catastrophique. Même ubichiotte n'aurait pas abusé à ce point, c'est dire le level.

Conquise, j'avais quelques doutes mais je recommande les yeux fermés pour les amateurs du studio. Normalement je ne suis pas spécialement fan des jeux narratifs mais celui ci fait exception (sans oublier les LIS évidemment). Touchant, profond, intriguant, équilibré : OUI !

Tells a really potent story and I hope we see more like this in the future.

Yeah, sometimes the gameplay gets in the way of what they are trying to do and sometimes the engine can't really rise to the writer's ambitions, but none of that really matters. The only thing that really bothered me was the choice to make Beach House the foundation of a soundtrack for a game about punk kids from '95. Even if you needed something a bit low-key for mood, there were future Lilith Fair mainstays available from the era. 

I was the same age as these characters in '95 and I certainly appreciated the nostalgia and am obviously old enough to identify with the adult versions of the characters. But I don't think that's a prerequisite here. If you're into narrative games, this is worth your while. 

Just sorry about the Beach House. I like Beach House. I've seen them live. Just not here.

Tenho só uma coisa que reclamara, pqp que jogo mau otimizado do krl em pqp, meu pc é forte p krl e rodou peidando, pqp deu raiva em alguns momentos, tirando isso é uma ótima experiencia.

I bought this game when only one "tape" had been released.
I loved it, i was captured and i couldn't wait for more.
However, after finally getting to playing the second half, i'm left deflated.
I felt the game was building, the slow intense intrigue.
Just to fall flat, hard.
This game, ultimately feels like it has no true ending.
The end, of course, in my own opinion, just gives more questions than answers.
The endings i thought up in my own head, lead on almost, by the game, were more adventurous and fulfilling.
The ending makes me feel hollow of what could have been.

Man bekommt ein typisches DON'T NOD Spiel und jeder der die Spiele des Studios mag, wird seinen Spa? damit haben. An Meisterwerke wie LiS 1 kommt es natürlich bei weitem nicht ran. Trotzdem ist es ein sch?nes Spiel, mit Herz und sch?ner Musik, aber in der Summe eher ein 7-8 / 10.
Lo amé

Lost Records: Bloom & Rage será um jogo fantástico para quem gosta de jogos de história com escolhas, tal como Life Is Strange (qualquer um da franquia), Tell Me Why, The Walking Dead, Beyond Two Souls etc. Tenho um grande apre?o por qualquer que seja o jogo, desde que tenha uma história boa e uma narrativa cativante, ent?o esse jogo serviu perfeitamente para mim.

No início, achei Bloom & Rage um pouco parado, isto é, na primeira fita, que demanda muitas horas, pois constrói a princípio a sua rela??o com a Kat, Autumn e Nora, e dá início ao mistério central do estranho buraco que aparece na floresta. N?o há muito impacto sobre as escolhas, e sim apenas sobre a rela??o das suas amigas com a protagonista Swann, que demanda de escolhas certas e bem pensadas, já que um errinho pode fazer sua rela??o ficar pior com elas, e isso tem certo impacto na segunda fita. 

Na última fita, a segunda, amei basicamente tudo nela. Vi que tem pessoas que n?o gostaram, e n?o entendo muito o motivo. Ela trás todo o impacto após o final marcante da primeira fita, mostra o motivo, embora de fato n?o nos dê muitas respostas. Querer viver sem ser vista inteiramente por seu maior problema, e fazer uma última coisa que sirva para te dar mais liberdade depois de uma vida trancafiada: foi exatamente o que aconteceu com a Kat, e ela teve a paz que merecia depois de tudo. Fiquei satisfeita, mesmo querendo mais resposta, e talvez algum dia nos tragam isso com alguma DLC ou algo do tipo, pois creio eu que todos que jogaram querem um maior aprofundamento nos mistérios mal resolvidos - explica??es mais plausíveis. 

A ambienta??o do jogo é linda, isso tudo num estilo mais retr?, com uma atmosfera que te prende do início ao fim, ainda mais nas partes tensas. Fiquei a todo momento curiosa para saber o que ia acontecer, e o final me surpreendeu bastante. Eu adorei as personagens apresentadas, por mais que eu sinta bastante falta de mais personagens para dar ainda mais profundidade ao jogo, seja mostrando os pais da Swann, os pais da Kat etc. Podiam ter mais fragmentos também da vida das outros personagens, fotos, textos, um pouco mais do cotidiano da Swann etc como no próprio LIS, e mais coisas e áreas exploráveis ao redor da cabana, o que daria mais respostas. Minha única crítica de verdade, é o estado em que o jogo saiu no lan?amento - ambas as fitas -, cheio de bugs de textura. Num desses bugs a Autumn ficava com a textura da roupa toda lascada, como se n?o tivesse roupa, algo que espero que tenham corrigido com essas novas atualiza??es, pois ainda vou rejogar para poder pegar a "platina".

Num geral, dou um 8,7/10 ao jogo. N?o acho que mere?a diretamente um 9 ou um 10, pois ainda poderiam ter mais coisas, coisas que tem em LIS, e que eu esperava que tivesse mais em Lost Records, por mais que seja um jogo diferente, mas que trariam mais profundidade ainda a narrativa.
Caso eu mude de opini?o rejogando, irei atualizar a nota.
Wow. DON'T NOD haben es ja doch noch drauf. Lange nicht mehr so ein stimmungsvolles Spiel gespielt.
Loved it

As a massive Life is Strange fan I was extremely excited to play a game from the original developers Dont Nod. I patiently waited on Lost Records being released but felt disappointed when it did. Firstly, I paid in full for the whole game, but found that I only had access to Tape 1 (the first part of the game) upon release (18 February, 2025). Despite paying for the game in its entirety, I wouldn't have access to Tape 2 until 2 whole months later (15 April 2025). Life is Strange used to be released in episodes, which is fine, but there should be an option to pay per tape for this game, not be charged full upfront then only be given access to half the content. As far as the game itself goes, the graphics are great. The game is quite glitchy and the menu bugs out at times and it has had a few patch updates since release. I feel like I spent more time in cutscenes than I did actually playing the game, which got a bit boring. As there was previously a photograph thing in LiS, Lost Records force a cam corder upon you where the game makes you take video recordings of things all the time, which is annoying and removes you from the immersion of the story a lot of the time. I didn't like this feature. The storyline was okay, but not the best. Overall the game was okay, but I don't think I'll be buying any future releases of this game unfortunately.

Another great game from DON'T NOD
If you liked Life is Strange, or just generally story games pick this game up

First off, I grew up in the 90s so I appreciated the care taken to give some sweet nostalgia moments. They really nailed this, and had me shrieking in delight at a few forgotten toys/items I used to own. 

The dialogue system was super clever. You’re able to interrupt mid sentence or as in real life, silence is sometimes golden. I prefer this innovative dialogue  approach and hope to see more games adopt it as it’s a lot more real life like.

I’ve played life is strange when it very first game out and I forgot how much closer these types of games are to a walking simulator. The story carried me along until the end but there were long periods where I felt I was doing nothing. A minor complaint as it’s a decent enough game, I personally would have prefer a few more puzzles….but for those coming for those life is strange feels then you won’t be disappointed. 

I must agree with other reviews that the ending left me a little confused. Lots of unanswered questions. Nevertheless, it’s an okay game and for the time I spent playing/watching - I had fun. Characters were well fleshed out and you do get invested in the story line.
Emotional story. For teenager truly) But really emotionally good

Jugué Lost Records: Bloom & Rage porque soy fan de Life is Strange, y no me ha decepcionado para nada. Desde el primer momento se nota el toque de los creadores: esa narrativa íntima, los personajes que parecen personas reales, y ese ambiente melancólico que solo ellos saben construir.

Me encantó la historia, pero sobre todo los peque?os detalles que conectan con Life is Strange. Son gui?os sutiles ―como los ciervos, las mariposas, el tono general― que me hicieron sonreír más de una vez. Puede que sean tonterías para algunos, pero para mí fueron un regalo.

La banda sonora es preciosa, la ambientación noventera está muy lograda y la forma en que se cuenta la historia, con saltos en el tiempo y relaciones complejas, me mantuvo enganchada hasta el final.

Si Life is Strange también fue especial para ti, te aseguro que Bloom & Rage te va a tocar el corazón. Muy recomendado.

I don't think I can recommend this game enough to other people. And trust me, I have been trying and trying as much as I can do spread the word. 
This game is beautiful. It's pure nostalgia wrapped up in a gorgeous layer of storytelling and friendship. It's the kind of thing you play to feel good, bad, nostalgic and ecstatic at the same time. 
The characters are phenomenal and they're all likeable in their own way. The little interactions between the girls and the callbacks to younger, more carefree times are something no game other than LiS1 managed to capture.
There are some negative sides, such as the optimization not being the greatest and tape 2 feeling slightly weaker than tape 1, but frankly in the grand scheme of things those are only minor.
I have not regretted a single cent I gave for this game, and if I had to, I'd buy it all over again. So please, stop reading this and go get it. Experience it for yourself. Because you will absolutely not regret it. DontNod, I'm hoping and praying that Tape 3 will be released. The girls deserve a proper ending.

It's been 27 years since Swann first stumbled onto the girls
It's been 10 years since I first stumbled onto the Episode 1 of Life is Strange. I was very touched by Max's story back then, but this one... man, this one is special.
Maybe, MAYBE! Lost Records is not the most heartbreaking thing in the world. But it certainly felt like one. 
What started as an intriguing mystery ended up giving me what others may only dream of providing - a most genuine view of another person's life. It wrecked me beyond repair.
I am without a doubt still unpacking what this game actually made me feel. It's like uncovering an entirely new emotion. A new dimension.

And don't even get me started on the technicalities...
If you invest yourself into this story, the authors really know how to make your experience more meaningful. Wherever you look there are always some carefully placed details that expand your perception of the narrative. The team continue to invent more and more clever and impactful ways to interact with the game. The writing is vibrant and profound. You are surrounded by real people with layers upon layers and beautiful internal contradictions. Dialog and overall interactive systems are so refined and more complex than anywhere else, perfectly reflecting our protagonist's internal world. 
and Camcorder is a genius touch and the heart of all of this. Perfection.

I'm not closely familiar with the games from Don't Nod, nor did I engage with a promo materials for this game, so I listened to the suggestion of my good friend and stepped into a wild unknown.

I think the game goes far beyond similar titles. The attention to detail is insane: the characters, scenery, music, and interactivity offer a great amount of story to perceive and to tell.

The characters seem so real and interesting that you could picture them in your life. The dialogues, from soothing to intense, will literally make you experience your thoughts running out of time. Every object in the game feels genuinely tactile. I could continue listing my experiences, but I think the most important one is that all these details are made coherent by the artistic vision of its creators. You can see the intent in every one of them, which makes this game so immersive - far more than just a sum of its parts.

In other words, Lost Records wants you to feel it all, make it yours, and hopefully, take it with you.

I spent hours talking about the game, at some point my friend said, "Soon we'll be discussing it longer than we played it." I'm telling you, we are so far past that point in time... I hope this game will click with you too, and you'll remember it, as it definitely deserves.
